segments.text: 1983, 1985 biennium.
It was gratifying to look back over the past 10 years and realize that I had passed five general appropriations bills in the Texas House and carried them to the conference committee with the Senate.
and it spanned a decade from 1975 to 1985.
Maybe the only decade in the history of Texas where there was never a special session on the appropriations bill and that there was no tax increase during that time.
There was an elimination
of taxes.
We removed the sales tax on utilities.
Being a graduate of Texas A&M, a former employee of A&M, and residing in Bryan College Station, I know that during that 10-year period I was perceived as
champion for higher education.
Life somewhat more uncomfortable than if I had had a different background and lived in a different location.
For years during the the decade 1975 to 85 that we were dealing with double-digit inflation and
rapid enrollments in all of our programs, including higher education, and an increase in population in the state.
I am proud of the support that I was able to give higher education as a whole and Texas A&M University System in particular.
And statistically speaking, higher education did fare well, but so did all of state government.
M University, for example, during that 10-year period, 1975 to 85, had
almost a 500% increase in general revenue appropriations, modest of any increases in any of the tuition and fees during that period, while experiencing an enrollment increase of 67%.
However, all of state government
increased its appropriations during that same period almost eight times, 800 percent.
Factoring out population and enrollment increases and inflation indicates
a rather flat enrollment during this period or flat appropriations during this period for both higher education and all of Texas state government.
I was proud of the achievements that we had made and it probably opened the door to other opportunities.
One time I had considered an appointment to a statewide office where there was a resignation.
Resignations occur, the governor makes those appointments.
And I had first asked the governor to consider me and
had my name withdrawn because of the fact that I was chairman of the House Appropriations Committee and want to disrupt the appropriations process by having to resign during a regular session.
So about this time that I was asked to consider a run for the U.S. Congress,
the opportunity was there since we had an open seat in our local congressional district.
I knew enough about serving in Congress that it was something that did not appeal to me at all.
I would have been willing to stay in the
Texas legislature and could have served for years to come as chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.
But with a paycheck of approximately $300 a month, it just did not have its financial rewards.
The Texas legislature, during the time I served,
provided adequately for office expenses and travel, but has a rather your salary for the time that it takes to serve.
We're fortunate in Texas to provide adequately for our legislators as far as their office holder requirements are concerned.
But there is a desperate need to increase the salary to at least cover the part time that one spends serving in the legislature.
I do not favor a full time salaried position in the legislature, but a person should be adequately compensated for the time that it takes and for the time that he spends.
In 1983, there was a considerable oil and gas play in Brazos County, and as a landowner, I stood to benefit from the oil and gas play
through royalty income on my property.
Very fortunate to be able to lease all of the land that I owned and have it all drilled.
The income from the flush production in 83 and then later in 84 was very good but it was of concern
to me that this would not last.
No one knew whether the wells that were being drilled in Brazos County would have much longevity.
And I did not feel like it was fair to my family to depend on that income for the future.
Out that it was rather short-lived production
But it was nice while it lasted.
